JUDGES: Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national and lives in GPE . She was represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

In DATE the applicant inherited a QUANTITY plot of land in GPE on the territory of the former GPE ( GPE ) ( “ the property ” ) and was registered in the land register as owner of the property . QUANTITY of the property had been used , DATE , as a road and were recorded as such in the registers of public roads in DATE and DATE . The applicant disputed that the relevant authorities of the GPE had designated the property as a public road as required by the laws of the GPE .

On DATE , and amended on DATE , the municipality made a written offer to the applicant , certified by a notary public , to buy the property for CARDINAL pursuant to LAW and Other Publicly Used Private Property – “ the Traffic Space Allocation Act ” ( Gesetz zur Bereinigung der Rechtsverhältnisse an LOC anderen öffentlich genutzten privaten ORG ) ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) .

On DATE ORG ordered the applicant to accept the offer . ORG held that the property was “ traffic space ” within the meaning of LAW ) No . CARDINAL of ORG ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) ; that the municipality had proved that the relevant authorities of the GPE had considered the road as a public road DATE and that it was therefore “ traffic space ” within the meaning of LAW ) No . CARDINAL of that Act ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) , since the laws of the GPE did not necessarily require the proper designation of property as a public road ; that all other requirements for the sale as required by ORG had been met ; and that the calculation of the purchase price was in accordance with the statutory requirements .

On DATE ORG informed counsel for the applicant of its intention to dismiss the applicant ’s appeal as manifestly ill - founded because ORG judgment , in particular concerning the qualification of the property as “ traffic space ” , had been free of error .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . It held that it could not consider the applicant ’s claim that only part of the property was used as a road whereas the whole property was to be taken on the following grounds : the municipality had stated before ORG that it had made an offer for the whole property because the remainder of the property could not be sufficiently used ; the applicant had not disputed this assertion in the proceedings before ORG ; his new submission that the taking of the whole property would be contrary to Sections CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) No . CARDINAL and GPE ) of ORG ( see “ Relevant domestic law and practice ” below ) was procedurally barred pursuant to LAW ( see “ Relevant domestic law and practice ” below ) .
On DATE ORG refused to admit the applicant ’s constitutional complaint for adjudication without giving further reasons ( no . CARDINAL BvR CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

In the GPE private property was often used for public purposes without the property being transferred into public ownership . Following NORP reunification the public use of private property was initially allowed to continue without any revision until DATE and the owners of such property were , under certain conditions , entitled to rent from the public authority pursuant to Section CARDINAL ) of LAW to LAW ( Einführungsgesetz zum PERSON ) .

Under LAW ( Sachenrechtsbereinigungsgesetz ) , owners were in principle entitled to PERCENT of the value of the land as compensation for the loss of the land ( Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW , is , as far as relevant here , inapplicable in cases concerning the use of private property for public purposes ( Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) No . CARDINAL of LAW ) ) .

With effect from DATE the continued use of private property on the territory of the former GPE is governed by ORG . That LAW is , inter alia , applicable if private property that was used as a public road by the authorities of the GPE continues to be used as a public road ( LAW ) of ORG ) . “ Traffic space ” is defined as roads , alleys and squares that are either designated as public roads or treated as if they were by law ( Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) No . CARDINAL of that Act ) . The public authority using private property for a public road may request that the property be sold to it by making a written offer , certified by a notary public ( Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of that Act ) . The public authority may only request the sale of the property directly used for a public road ( Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) No . CARDINAL of that Act ) ; it has to purchase the remainder the property only if it can not be sufficiently used ( Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of that Act ) . The purchase price is PERCENT of the value of the land ( LAW ) . Until DATE only the public authority could request the sale ; since that date , only the private owner can do so ( Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of that Act ) . Until the sale has been concluded , the owner can request that the public authority pay him PERCENT of the statutory purchase price as DATE rent and bear the public expenses of the property ; the public authority has the right to continue using the property pending the transfer of ownership ( Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of that Act ) . If the sold property is no longer used as a public road , the former owner can request that the property be sold to him for a certain purchase price ( Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of that Act ) .

The former owner can request the restitution of property irrespective of a public authority ’s continuing use of it pursuant to ORG . The public authority continues to enjoy a right to use the property following the return of the property to the former owner ORG , judgment of DATE , no . BVerwG CARDINAL C CARDINAL.CARDINAL ) .

In cases in which the public authority ’s right to use the private property derived from Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG , the right to use prior to that Act ’s coming into force derived from Section CARDINAL ) of LAW to LAW ( ORG , judgment of DATE , V ZR CARDINAL ) .

ORG held in a leading judgment of DATE ( no . V ZR CARDINAL ) that the purchase price of PERCENT of the value of the land pursuant to LAW was constitutional on the grounds that the property had been used as a public road in the GPE and could not have been sold or used by the private owner prior to NORP reunification ; that the value of the property was diminished by the public use ; that the legislator had taken into account that not the owner but upon request the public authority had to bear expenses related to the property ; and that the public authority ’s right to use was considerably more limited than that of a user who acquired the property under the terms of LAW : whereas the latter could stop using the property and nevertheless remain the owner , the public authority was bound to sell the property to the former owner for a certain purchase price on request once it had stopped using the property as “ traffic space ” . Furthermore ORG held that the contested provisions of ORG did not violate the owner ’s rights under LAW No . CARDINAL read alone or in conjunction with LAW . Although the sale amounted to a de facto expropriation within the meaning of LAW No . CARDINAL , it had a basis in domestic law , was in the general interest and not disproportionate . In particular , the legislator had acted within the wide margin of appreciation to be accorded to him in the unique context of the NORP reunification .

Pursuant to LAW shall base its decision on the facts established by the first instance court , unless there are concrete indications that raise doubts as to the correctness or completeness of the establishment of the relevant facts by the first instance court , and on new facts , as long as it is admissible to consider these .

ORG may not consider submissions that the trial court has correctly excluded ( Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ) . It may , as far as relevant here , admit new submissions on appeal only if the party did not introduce them at trial through no fault of its own ( LAW ) No . CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure ) .
